questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents with a sore throat and difficulty breathing. Two days ago, she started experiencing cough, congestion, runny nose, low-grade fever, and body aches. Today, her cough worsened and started producing yellow phlegm. She feels short of breath, and her mother is concerned about a “funny sound” with her breathing that started this afternoon. She has had a diminished appetite and limited fluid intake. She is up to date with all of her vaccinations, including Covid-19, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
On examination, she has a body temperature of 39.0°C, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 90% while breathing ambient air. She appears tired, anxious, and ill, with increased work of breathing. Examination of the head, eyes, ears, nose, and throat reveals nasal congestion. The patient is not drooling but has audible inspiratory stridor and moderate intercostal retractions that do not improve upon administration of racemic epinephrine. Breath sounds are heard in both lung fields with no wheezing or rales. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s illness?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute laryngotracheitis, or croup, typically occurs in younger children (<3 years of age). It may be caused by a variety of respiratory viruses, most commonly parainfluenza virus type 1. Although children with acute laryngotracheitis can have high fevers (as this patient does), they usually respond to racemic epinephrine and do not appear as ill or toxic; in addition, this patient is well outside the typical age range for infectious croup.

B) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes (group A streptococcus) and Moraxella catarrhalis c an cause bacterial tracheitis, but they are not the most common causes of the illness.

C) INCORRECT:

The presentation of epiglottitis has some similar features to that of bacterial tracheitis. However, epiglottitis typically manifests with abrupt onset of rapidly progressing symptoms, namely dysphagia, drooling, and distress. It is most commonly caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib). With the addition of the Hib vaccine to the routine childhood immunization series, the incidence of epiglottitis has declined significantly.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is most consistent with bacterial tracheitis, an exudative bacterial infection of the trachea that typically occurs after a viral respiratory infection, most commonly influenza. Patients often report 1 to 3 days of minor viral respiratory symptoms, followed by progression to more-severe symptoms, including respiratory distress and fever.

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of bacterial tracheitis. Both methicillin-sensitive and methicillin-resistant S. aureus should be considered when choosing empiric antibiotic therapy.

Key learning point: The organism most commonly implicated in bacterial tracheitis is Staphylococcus aureus.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes (group A streptococcus) and Moraxella catarrhalis c an cause bacterial tracheitis, but they are not the most common causes of the illness.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a high fever that began 5 hours ago. He has had a sore throat and cough for the past 3 days. Today, he refused to eat, became increasingly lethargic, and developed a fever that did not respond to acetaminophen at home. His past medical history is unremarkable. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears ill and somnolent. His temperature is 39.8°C (103.6°F), pulse is 140/min, and respirations are 30/min. Physical examination shows stridor, rhinorrhea, and a productive cough with copious purulent sputum. The patient's stridor does not improve with the administration of nebulized racemic epinephrine. Anteroposterior and lateral neck x-rays show subglottic narrowing and irregularities of the tracheal wall. Which of the following is the most likely causal infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Parainfluenza virus is the most common cause of croup, which has a 1–2 day prodromal phase and can cause cough, subglottic narrowing (visible as a steeple sign on a neck x-ray), and stridor in moderate to severe cases. However, patients with croup typically present with a low-grade fever and a nonproductive barking cough, and stridor improves with the administration of nebulized racemic epinephrine.

B) INCORRECT:

Following the advent of the Hib vaccine, Streptococcus pyogenes is now a common cause of epiglottitis. This condition manifests with the rapid onset of high-grade fever, stridor, and a toxic appearance, and symptoms do not improve with the administration of nebulized racemic epinephrine. However, characteristic findings on lateral neck x-ray include thumb sign with supraglottic rather than subglottic narrowing. S. pyogenes can also cause bacterial tracheitis, but it is not the most common causal agent.

C) INCORRECT:

Respiratory diphtheria is a rare cause of stridor and is typically preceded by a 4–5 day prodrome of fever, sore throat, and malaise. Due to the destruction and subsequent inflammation of the upper respiratory epithelium, patients present with pseudomembranes on the tonsils and pharyngeal wall, and significant cervical lymphadenopathy (bull neck appearance). Due to widespread pediatric immunization against diphtheria, most cases now occur in adults, after the effects of childhood immunization have waned.

D) INCORRECT:

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection is the most common cause of bronchiolitis, which usually occurs in patients < 6 months of age and manifests with wheezing, crackles, and rhonchi on lung auscultation. Radiographic findings of bronchiolitis include peribronchial thickening and hyperinflated lungs. Stridor and irregular subglottic narrowing indicate a different diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

A rapid onset of high-grade fever, productive cough, and stridor in combination with subglottic narrowing and tracheal wall irregularities on imaging indicates bacterial tracheitis, which is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. This condition is rare but potentially life-threatening and necessitates immediate airway stabilization, followed by initiation of empiric IV antibiotics and bronchoscopy for both diagnostic confirmation and therapeutic airway debridement. Stridor caused by bacterial tracheitis does not improve with nebulized racemic epinephrine, unlike stridor due to croup. Bronchoscopy typically reveals tracheal edema, pseudomembranous exudates, and purulent secretions. Less common causes of bacterial tracheitis include Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, and Moraxella catarrhalis.

See “Infectious causes of airway obstruction” table.
questions.hint: The most common cause of bullous impetigo is also the most likely pathogen responsible for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a 3-day history of barking cough, hoarseness, and stridor that worsens at night. The child appears unwell. Vital signs are BP, 90/50; P, 140; R, 50; T, 40.1°C (104.2°F). Physical examination shows intercostal retractions. Nebulized racemic epinephrine and dexamethasone are administered, and the child shows minimal improvement after 3 hours of observation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of an ill-appearing child with high fever and poor response to standard croup treatment strongly suggests bacterial tracheitis. This condition requires immediate antibiotic therapy with broad-spectrum coverage while preparing for potential difficult airway management and ENT consultation.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient needs airway management, rapid sequence intubation (RSI) is a high-risk procedure in children with likely bacterial tracheitis, who have multiple difficult intubation conditions and typically benefit from advanced airway management in the operating room by airway specialists (e.g., ENT, anesthesia). Attempting an immediate RSI without an appropriate difficult airway management strategy could precipitate a cannot intubate-cannot ventilate scenario.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has classic features of bacterial tracheitis, which does not respond to standard croup treatments. Additional dexamethasone is unlikely to provide benefit.

D) INCORRECT:

Chest x-ray can be obtained as part of the workup but should not delay treatment of the most likely underlying condition affecting this patient's airway.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeated nebulized epinephrine may provide temporary relief in viral croup, but this patient's lack of response to initial treatment suggests a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents to the ED with worsening stridor and respiratory distress despite receiving oral dexamethasone for presumed croup earlier that day. His symptoms began two days ago with a low-grade fever and hoarse voice, but he is now febrile and toxic appearing. Vital signs are BP, 96/58 mm Hg; P, 142; R, 36; T, 39.2°C (102.6°F); SpO₂, 90% on room air. Examination reveals inspiratory and expiratory stridor, copious thick secretions, and moderate intercostal retractions. He is started on supplemental oxygen and given a nebulized racemic epinephrine treatment with minimal improvement. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer another nebulized racemic epinephrine treatment
Prepare for airway stabilization and start empiric antibiotics
Administer intravenous antibiotics and obtain urgent neck x-rays
Give intravenous corticosteroids, empiric antibiotics, and obtain urgent CT neck with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Repeat nebulized epinephrine may temporarily improve symptoms of viral croup but is ineffective in this child's diagnosis. Continued reliance on croup therapy can delay airway protection and definitive management.

B) CORRECT:

Correct — Bacterial tracheitis presents with severe upper airway obstruction, high fever, and toxic appearance unresponsive to croup treatment. The priority is airway stabilization, ideally with controlled intubation by the most experienced clinician, followed by IV antibiotics covering Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA) and Streptococcus species, such as vancomycin plus a third-generation cephalosporin.

C) INCORRECT:

While neck x-rays may show subglottic narrowing, obtaining imaging delays critical airway management in a child with severe respiratory distress and signs of impending airway obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

This approach would be appropriate for suspected retropharyngeal abscess, where imaging confirms a localized deep neck space infection. However, this patient's symptoms are in keeping with bacterial tracheitis involves diffuse infection and mucopurulent sloughing of the tracheal mucosa, often causing critical airway obstruction. CT neck would not change the management in this case and delaying airway stabilization to obtain imaging is dangerous. Corticosteroids are widely used to treat airway edema but there is a paucity of evidence supporting their use in both retropharyngeal abscess and bacterial tracheitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cricothyrotomy is a last-resort procedure in children due to anatomical limitations and high complication risk. Most patients with bacterial tracheitis can be managed with controlled orotracheal intubation in the operating room by an experienced airway team.
